\chapter{Folder structure}
\label{\detokenize{folder_structure:folder-structure}}\label{\detokenize{folder_structure::doc}}
Here is the folder structure of the code:

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] .
\item[] ├── bin
\item[] ├── gravity
\item[] │   ├── commons\_multigrid
\item[] │   ├── mond\_mass
\item[] │   └── newton
\item[] │             └── fft\_solver
\item[] ├── grid
\item[] ├── libs
\item[] ├── pm
\item[] ├── tests
\item[] └── time\_evolution
\end{DUlineblock}

Details:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin}} contains the Makefile

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gravity}} contains the gravity solvers.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gravity/commons\_multigrid}} suport routines for multigrid solvers which do not depend on the model.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gravity/mond\_mass}} constains the multigrid solver for the model we are dealing with (MOND with mass terms).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gravity/newton}} contains an FFT based solver for Poisson’s equation (needed for standard simulations).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grid}} all routines related to the grid including allocation routines and initialization of the FFTW variables.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{libs}} miscelaneous including cosmology, utility files for allocating 3D arrays and routines for reading parameter files.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pm}} (particle mesh).  Everything related to the particles at their connection to the grid.  Here we allocate memory for particles and transfer information from the particles trough the grid (for calculatign density in the grid) and viceversa (for calculating force in the particles).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests}} has routines for testing.  Here you can find the routines for the spherical test.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{time\_evolution}} contains the main time loop.

\end{itemize}


\chapter{Data structure}
\label{\detokenize{data_structure:data-structure}}\label{\detokenize{data_structure::doc}}
We have the following structures defined in the code:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{params}}: defined in solve.h.  It contains input parameters and some physical constants (including expansion factor).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parts}}: defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pm/init\_parts.h}}.  It contains particles’ positions and velocities, which are allocated in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pm/init\_parts.c}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grids}}: defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grid/init\_grid.h}}.  If contains all the fields and space for doing FFTs.  Eveything is allocated in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grid/init\_grid.h}}.  Note that there are additional grids allocated by the multigrid solver.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grids\_gravity\_mm}}: defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gravity/mond\_mass/solve\_multigrid\_mm.h}}.  It contains everything related to the MOND\sphinxhyphen{}MM multigrid solver (including the coarse grids, which are allocated in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gravity/mond\_mass/solve\_multigrid\_mm.c}}.

\end{itemize}

Detailed definitions follow:

\chapter{files}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/files:files}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/files::doc}}

\section{gravity}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/gravity:gravity}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/gravity::doc}}

\subsection{mond\_mass}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/mond_mass:mond-mass}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/mond_mass::doc}}

\subsubsection{cycles\_mm.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/cycles_mm_c:cycles-mm-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/cycles_mm_c::doc}}
Here is the V cycle of multigrid iterations.

Since our first grid is number zero, we go to coarse grids by going up,
so the cycle is inverted.
\begin{description}
\item[{Converge criteria:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
See box in page 157 of Trottenberg, Oosterlee, Schuller, “Multigrid” for details.

\item {} 
The convergence criteria are based on the mean value of the residual

\item {} 
What we mean by “mean value” is defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grid/get\_mean\_max\_two\_fields}}.

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{We have three criteria:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Absolute value of the residual (which has units, so it is not good).

\item {} 
Ratio of residual of latest step and first step.  This is the one implemented in Ramses.  It depends on how good or bad the initial guess is, so it makes no sence.

\item {} 
Comparison with truncation error.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\index{cycle\_v\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{cycle\_v\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/cycles_mm_c:c.cycle_v_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{int \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{cycle\_v\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{a}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{cycle\_v\_mm\_recursive (C function)@\spxentry{cycle\_v\_mm\_recursive}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/cycles_mm_c:c.cycle_v_mm_recursive}}%
\pysigstartmultiline

\subsubsection{differential\_operators\_mm.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/differential_operators_mm_c:differential-operators-mm-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/differential_operators_mm_c::doc}}
Definition of the differential operator for both equations (Poisson like and MOND like).
\index{L\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{L\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/differential_operators_mm_c:c.L_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{L\_mm}}}{double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{chi}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{aa0}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{a2M2}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{h}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{fourh}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{i}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{j}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{k}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{ip1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{im1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{jp1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{jm1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{kp1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{km1}, double *\sphinxstyleemphasis{operator\_phi}, double *\sphinxstyleemphasis{operator\_chi}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Evaluates differential operators on a node

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{evaluate\_differential\_operator\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{evaluate\_differential\_operator\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/differential_operators_mm_c:c.evaluate_differential_operator_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{evaluate\_differential\_operator\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{grid}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{chi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{operator\_phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{operator\_chi}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Evaluates differential operators on the grid given by the second argument.
Note that the grid does not have to necessarily be the grid gg\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{}g.
we do not store the result in the correponding variables in gg (instead
we store it in the arguments res\_phi, res\_chi).  This is in case you wat
to store it somewhere else.

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection{go\_up\_and\_down\_mm.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/go_up_and_down_mm_c:go-up-and-down-mm-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/go_up_and_down_mm_c::doc}}
Two routines for going to coarse (up) and fine (down) grids.
\index{go\_down\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{go\_down\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/go_up_and_down_mm_c:c.go_down_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{go\_down\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{a}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Moves everything to the next finer grid
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
gg\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{}g is the coarse.

\item {} 
gg\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{}g\sphinxhyphen{}1 fine

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{go\_up\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{go\_up\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/go_up_and_down_mm_c:c.go_up_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{go\_up\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.params}]{\sphinxcrossref{params}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{par}, \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{a}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline~\begin{description}
\item[{Moves everything to the next coarser grid.}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Calculates source in coarse grid.

\item {} 
Transfer density and solution.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

See box in Trottenberg, pag 157.
\begin{description}
\item[{The source is calculated with:}] \leavevmode
S = operator(R(phi), R(rho), R(S)) \sphinxhyphen{} R(residual(phi, rho, S))

\item[{For first term:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Restrict three fields (including the source in this level, which is zero in the fine grid).

\item {} 
Evaluate operator.

\end{itemize}

\item[{For the second term:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Calculate the residual in the level where we are.

\item {} 
Restrict that residual.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsubsection{gs\_residual\_truncation\_error\_mm.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/gs_residual_truncation_error_mm_c:gs-residual-truncation-error-mm-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/gs_residual_truncation_error_mm_c::doc}}
Routines for doing one Gauss\sphinxhyphen{}Seidel sweep, calculating residual and
truncation error (all in one grid).
\begin{quote}

Note:
This is basically the core of the solver where the equations are included.
See also \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{differential\_operators\_mm.c}}.
\end{quote}
\index{gs\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{gs\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/gs_residual_truncation_error_mm_c:c.gs_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{gs\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{gs\_node\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{gs\_node\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/gs_residual_truncation_error_mm_c:c.gs_node_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{gs\_node\_mm}}}{double \sphinxstyleemphasis{rho}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{source\_phi}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{source\_chi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{chi}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{cte\_poisson\_over\_a}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{aa0}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{a2M2}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{h}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{fourh}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{i}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{j}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{k}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{ip1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{im1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{jp1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{jm1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{kp1}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{km1}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
This routine does Gauss\sphinxhyphen{}Seidel (GS) iteration in one node.
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
There are a lot of arguments to prevent the routine from accessing the pointer to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grids\_gravity\_mm}}
and make it more efficient.

\item {} 
Whatever you put here is crucial for the performance of the code.  In particular, “if” statements can kill the performance.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{residual\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{residual\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/gs_residual_truncation_error_mm_c:c.residual_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{residual\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{grid}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{res\_phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{res\_chi}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Calculates residual on the grid “grid”.
Comments:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Note that the grid does not have to necessarily be the grid gg\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{}g.

\item {} 
We do not store the result by default in the correponding variables in gg (instead we store it in
the arguments res\_phi, res\_chi).  This is in case you wat to store it somewhere else.

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{trunc\_err\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{trunc\_err\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/gs_residual_truncation_error_mm_c:c.trunc_err_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{trunc\_err\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, int \sphinxstyleemphasis{grid}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{trunc\_phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{trunc\_chi}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Estimates truncation error (i.e. error associated to the discretizatio of the differential equation).
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Note that the grid does not have to necessarily be the grid gg\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{}g.

\item {} 
The estimator is: tau = P{[} D(R(phi)) \sphinxhyphen{} R(D(phi)) {]}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsubsection{initial\_guess\_mm.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/initial_guess_mm_c:initial-guess-mm-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/initial_guess_mm_c::doc}}
Initial guess for multigrid solver.
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Use this if you do not have a better solution (such as the solution
is previous time step).

\item {} 
This must be called before you call the multigrid solver.

\item {} 
For the MOND case, zero is not good enough (that’s why we put a
random number).

\item {} 
A better initial guesses can be otained by what we have in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{solve\_spherical\_mond}}.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\index{initial\_guess\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{initial\_guess\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/initial_guess_mm_c:c.initial_guess_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{initial\_guess\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.params}]{\sphinxcrossref{params}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{par}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{chi\_bar}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi\_bar}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
\end{fulllineitems}



\subsubsection{solve\_multigrid\_mm.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_multigrid_mm_c:solve-multigrid-mm-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_multigrid_mm_c::doc}}
Multigrid solver for the non\sphinxhyphen{}linear Bekenstein\sphinxhyphen{}Milgrom MM equation
in a 3D uniform grid given a source.
See Brent 1977, Trottenberg 2000 or Wesseling 1992.
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
User should give and initial condition in phi for the iterations
(zero is wrong).

\item {} 
Grids start from zero, meaning that the V cycle looks more like an
inverted V (i.e. when we go up, we go to coarse grids).

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\index{allocate\_grids\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{allocate\_grids\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_multigrid_mm_c:c.allocate_grids_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{allocate\_grids\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{dens}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{chi}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Allocate additional coarse grids for the multigrid solver.
For the fine grid, we do not make a copy, but just keep a pointer
to the variables in the main structure par.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{deallocate\_grids\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{deallocate\_grids\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_multigrid_mm_c:c.deallocate_grids_mm}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{deallocate\_grids\_mm}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.grids_gravity_mm}]{\sphinxcrossref{grids\_gravity\_mm}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{gg}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{dens}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{chi}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Clean up the coarse grids.
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
We do not clean up the fine grid because we only have a pointer to the
main variables in the main code (in the structure \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{grid}}).

\item {} 
We could call this after obtaining a solution.  Which means that we
have to allocate everything again in the following time step.
I am not sure if that is the best thing to do, but in any case,
the overhead is negligible compare with everything else.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{solve\_multigrid\_mm (C function)@\spxentry{solve\_multigrid\_mm}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection{solve\_spherical\_mond.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_spherical_mond_c:solve-spherical-mond-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_spherical_mond_c::doc}}
Routines for solving for the spherical mond potential given by
the standard poisson’s equation.
The calculation of the source and everything is made here.
\sphinxhyphen{} See appendix in Llinares’ thesis 2010.
\index{pow2 (C macro)@\spxentry{pow2}\spxextra{C macro}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\index{solve\_spherical\_mond (C function)@\spxentry{solve\_spherical\_mond}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/mond_mass/solve_spherical_mond_c:c.solve_spherical_mond}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{int \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{solve\_spherical\_mond}}}{double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{phi}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{a}, fftw\_complex *\sphinxstyleemphasis{data}, fftw\_plan \sphinxstyleemphasis{p\_forward}, fftw\_plan \sphinxstyleemphasis{p\_backward}, double \sphinxstyleemphasis{power\_a0}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
This routine comes from the thesis.  It has to be merged into the new
code.  It is not included in the Makefile.

The routine solves an equation for the spherical mond potential which can
be obtained by calculating the derivative of the integral (yes, that’s
what I wrote) of the MOND equation.
The method is:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
get newtonian forces.

\item {} 
get spherical mond forces.

\item {} 
take divergence.

\item {} 
solve poisson’s equation with that source.

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{phi = newtonian potential.}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{a = expansion factor.}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}}}) \textendash{} 

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
phi = spherical mondian potential.

\end{itemize}


\end{description}\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
No units (they come with whatever you put as input).

\item {} 
THIS ROUTINE REWITES PHI.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{newton}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/newton:newton}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/newton::doc}}

\subsubsection{fft\_solver}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/fft_solver/fft_solver:fft-solver}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/fft_solver/fft_solver::doc}}

\paragraph{solve\_poisson\_fftw.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/fft_solver/solve_poisson_fftw_c:solve-poisson-fftw-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/fft_solver/solve_poisson_fftw_c::doc}}
Solve Poisson’s equation in a 3D uniform grid given a source.
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
No 4 pi G involved (it should come with the source if there is any).

\item {} 
You can get the 4 pi G for standard gravity by calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{calc\_newt\_source}}.

\item {} 
No units (again, they should come with the density).

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\subsubsection{calc\_newt\_source.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/calc_newt_source_c:calc-newt-source-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/newton/calc_newt_source_c::doc}}
Calculates the source of standard Poisson’s equation.
Comments:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
This routine can probably be simplified, but having this separate from the
solver allow us to used the FFT solver for many things (for instance, for
calculating initial conditions for the MOND equation.

\end{itemize}

\subsection{prolonge.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/prolonge_c:prolonge-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/prolonge_c::doc}}
Prologation routines which interpolate a field from a coarse grid back to a fine grid.
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
See Trottenberg, Oosterlee, Schuller, “Multigrid” for details.

\item {} 
These routines are needed by the multigrid solver to move between grids.

\item {} 
There are several routines that use different interpolation order.  Higher order is not necessarily better.

\item {} 
The only public routine is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{prolonge}}.  The other routines are accessed through it.  Uncomment the call you want to use.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\index{pow2 (C macro)@\spxentry{pow2}\spxextra{C macro}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/prolonge_c:c.pow2}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{pow2}}}{\sphinxstyleemphasis{x}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{restrict.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/restrict_c:restrict-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/restrict_c::doc}}
Restriction routines which interpolate a field from a fina grid to a coarse grid (with half the number of points per dimension).
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
See Trottenberg, Oosterlee, Schuller, “Multigrid” for details.

\item {} 
These routines are needed by the multigrid solver to move between grids.

\item {} 
There are several routines that use different interpolation order.  Higher order is not necessarily better.

\item {} 
The only public routine is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{restrict\_grid}}.  The other routines are accessed through it.  Uncomment the call you want to use.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\subsection{get\_gravity.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/get_gravity_c:get-gravity-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/gravity/get_gravity_c::doc}}

density and potential).
\begin{description}
\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The result is returned in the corresponding variable in the grid
structure.

\item {} 
The density and potential will also end up in the coresponding
variables in the structure grid.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\section{grid}

\section{pm}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/pm/pm:pm}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/pm/pm::doc}}

\subsection{calc\_delta\_cic.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/pm/calc_delta_cic_c:calc-delta-cic-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/pm/calc_delta_cic_c::doc}}
Calculates overdensity on the grid from the particle’s positions using cloud
in cell (CIC) smoothing.
Comments:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Details in the CIC scheme can be found in
Hockney R. W., Eastwood J. W., 1988, Computer simulation using particles.

\end{itemize}
\index{calc\_delta\_cic (C function)@\spxentry{calc\_delta\_cic}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/pm/calc_delta_cic_c:c.calc_delta_cic}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{calc\_delta\_cic}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.params}]{\sphinxcrossref{params}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{par}, \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/solve_h:c.units}]{\sphinxcrossref{units}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{unit}, double *\sphinxstyleemphasis{pos\_1}, double *\sphinxstyleemphasis{pos\_2}, double *\sphinxstyleemphasis{pos\_3}, double ***\sphinxstyleemphasis{delta}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Calculates overdensity on the grid from the particle’s positions
using cloud in cell (CIC) smoothing..

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
This is a note for testign Sphinx.
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{par}} \textendash{} par structure.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{unit}} \textendash{} units structure.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{pos\_1}} \textendash{} X component of position vector.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{pos\_2}} \textendash{} X component of position vector.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{pos\_3}} \textendash{} X component of position vector.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{delta}} \textendash{} to return overdensity.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Overdensity in the parameter delta, which should be allocated.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

Comments:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Units in the input file are expected to be Mpc/h for the positions and km/sec for the velocities.

Units are converted later to Mpc and Mpc/Gyr.

\end{itemize}

\section{init\_physics.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/init_physics_c:init-physics-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/init_physics_c::doc}}\index{init\_physics (C function)@\spxentry{init\_physics}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/init_physics_c:c.init_physics}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{init\_physics}}}{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{data_structure:c.params}]{\sphinxcrossref{params}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{par}, \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{struct}} {\hyperref[\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/solve_h:c.units}]{\sphinxcrossref{units}}} *\sphinxstyleemphasis{unit}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Initializes a lot of physical constants including the factor in front of
the density in the Poisson’s equation (which somehow contains the effective
gravitational constant).  So if you want to change \$G\$, this is probably
the place to do it.   Although, keep in mind that additional changes
are made later on to include the dependence with expansion factor.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{par}} \textendash{} parameter structure.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{unit}} \textendash{} units structure.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Changes are included in the two structures that you input.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/init_physics_h:init-physics-h}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/init_physics_h::doc}}\index{init\_physics (C function)@\spxentry{init\_physics}\spxextra{C function}}

\section{solve.c}
\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/solve_c:solve-c}}\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/solve_c::doc}}
Here is the main function.
\begin{description}
\item[{Units:}] \leavevmode\begin{description}
\item[{input:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{[}x{]} = Mpc/h

\item {} 
{[}v{]} = km sec\textasciicircum{}\sphinxhyphen{}1

\end{itemize}

\item[{internal:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{[}x{]} = Mpc

\item {} 
{[}v{]} = Mpc/Gyr

\item {} 
{[}source{]} = 1/Gyr\textasciicircum{}2

\item {} 
{[}phi{]} = Mpc\textasciicircum{}2/Gyr\textasciicircum{}2 (it takes units from distances)

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item[{Comments:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The program can NOT restart.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\index{main (C function)@\spxentry{main}\spxextra{C function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{sphinx-c-apidoc/output/solve_c:c.main}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{int \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{main}}}{int \sphinxstyleemphasis{argc}, char *\sphinxstyleemphasis{argv}{[}{]}}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
Main routine.  It initializes everything (physics, fine grid and particles) and gives control to the routine that does the time evolution.

\end{fulllineitems}
